title: Alright Riot you need to explain what Willump is.
body: I mean seriously what is he? Speaking just biologically he makes no sense with anything we have seen so far. Creatures don't normally just grow extra limbs from nothing, evolution normally works with what it has as a base and builds off that. So did land dwelling animals evolve twice? Are there other 6 limbed creatures out there? If not what is he? Where did he come from? We need answers.

replies.body: Personally, I like to leave certain things unsaid X). Keeps some of the mystery around. I call it the "Midichlorian Problem" :D

My personal head cannon is that Willump is a really, really ancient and grown up Poro.

Try to stop me.
It's OK, you can just call him a bullymong. Assuming gearbox won't whine about it...

> [{quoted}](name=Provengreil,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=00000001,timestamp=2018-08-15T01:25:42.150+0000)
>
> It's OK, you can just call him a bullymong. Assuming gearbox won't whine about it...

:thinking emoji: hmmmm

You can either say Willump is a Bonerfart. Sir Hammerlock approved!

Edit: in the meanwhile tempered Kirin is Butt Stallion confurmed
So you are saying you neither comfirm or deny the existence of any biological ancestors?

> [{quoted}](name=Bazerka,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2018-08-14T23:04:35.432+0000)
>
> Personally, I like to leave certain things unsaid X). Keeps some of the mystery around. I call it the "Midichlorian Problem" :D

It would be an issue if we were explaining the magic of the League of Legends universe...but this is us wanting to know more about a certain race of Yeti. Just a bit more info about them wouldnt hurt.
My problem is that it feels like thats the answer for everything
why tho

he's... magic

six limbed reptiles don't exist in nature either, no one's complaining about dragons.
are you sure

He's the last (and currently only depiction of) a modern yeti, so yeah yetis probably evolved 4 arms. They're also clearly heavily shaped and developed by magic and not just physical natural selection.

But it is strange that yeti's evolved four arms, that would require major divergence from their last common ancestor. Not saying it's impossible but it is far more likely that there would be other species that evolved from a similar 6 limbed ancestor.

> [{quoted}](name=Wayward Son,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=00020000,timestamp=2018-08-14T23:23:09.788+0000)
>
> But it is strange that yeti's evolved four arms, that would require major divergence from their last common ancestor. Not saying it's impossible but it is far more likely that there would be other species that evolved from a similar 6 limbed ancestor.

Why are you assuming that runeterra evolved? For all you know aurelian sols dad created it for fun and thought four armed yetis were cute?? 

It's a fictional world it doesn't have to abide by the same rules and the real world.

Because unless specified otherwise, fictional worlds mirror their real life counter parts. Handwaving it away and saying it's just fantasy is bad storytelling. If something did create all the life on Runeterra then that is something stories should be written about.

> [{quoted}](name=Wayward Son,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=0002000000020000,timestamp=2018-08-14T23:40:16.479+0000)
>
> Because unless specified otherwise, fictional worlds mirror their real life counter parts. Handwaving it away and saying it's just fantasy is bad storytelling. If something did create all the life on Runeterra then that is something stories should be written about.

The fuck is this logic. That's like arguing that every creature in fantasy novels must be huminoid unless specified separately. Or arguing that every character  must look like the reader unless specified differently. Some people like to leave things to the imagination. And that isn't inherently bad storytelling. In fact leaving things to the imagination can encourage readers to actively participate in the story instead of having everything dictated to them.

That's not at all what I'm saying. If something is a four armed four legged spider person it must be safe to assume it comes from a place where that is considered normal, or has an explanation of why it exists otherwise.

> [{quoted}](name=Wayward Son,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=000200000002000000000000,timestamp=2018-08-14T23:54:27.779+0000)
>
> That's not at all what I'm saying. If something is a four armed four legged spider person it must be safe to assume it comes from a place where that is considered normal, or has an explanation of why it exists otherwise.

No. It's not safe to assume anything. That's rediculous. It's a world that you are allowed to see through slits in the wood. Your trying to rationalize everything. That's not how you can approach this. It's fair to ask questions. But your starting from the assumption that you understand the biology and chemistry of a world with magic. That's silly. 

Magic doesn't exist in this world. So based on that alone we should assume that the world is literally nothing like ours. There is literally no reason to assume that the laws which govern our world have any influence whatsoever on that world unless it's reflected in the stories. 

You first read the stories and try to figure out what you can and what is 'real' from them. And after that you can theory crafting and ask questions. You do not start from the assumption you understand everything and then wait for something to disprove you. It's an insult to the writer.

"It's not safe to assume anything."


Point of Order: Basic worldbuilding disagrees. If a fantasy setting tells me that a Yeti has 4 arms, I'm game, Yetis have 4 arms. If all the other Yetis have 2 arms, and all their ancestors have 2 arms, and we're told of at least one of these facts, now this needs addressing.*

Now, the rules of evolution properly applied millions of years backward is admittedly something you gotta let go of with any world not designed with the help of an evolutionary biologist or two. Instead, the go to rule is that creatures of the same species have forms little further apart than your typical pair of randomly selected humans.

Runeterra follows the latter rule, and the only hint that the former even exists is Gnar. Humans are humans, and every one of them that rises above the pack/becomes different gets explicit lore about him telling us why. Same with Yordles. Void creatures are explicitly different from each other because they don't originate in the same way normal life does outside of the void. We see one of plenty of species (Zyra, Nami, Soraka, Anivia, Bard, and Rengar to name a few) but have no reason the believe they are unique in the world. 

This, from a species perspective as we learn what we see, makes a couple problem children, but in fact the only examples I can find are yordles( either version of Willump is unique in our vision of the world. We have no comparison). Fizz has been brought up, and both tristana and lulu are lacking fur with purple skin. If it was just Lulu I'd say unstable transformation magic applied with questionable sanity, but tristana has no explanation here.

*It doesn't have to be addressed _well_. Radiation? Magic? Genetic manipulation? Sure, let's go.
It was stated that male yordles have more fur in order to attract female yordles. However I dont know if that still holds up with Yordles now being spirits.

> [{quoted}](name=Provengreil,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=00020000000200000000000000000002,timestamp=2018-08-15T01:47:10.710+0000)
>
> "It's not safe to assume anything."
> 
> 
> Point of Order: Basic worldbuilding disagrees. If a fantasy setting tells me that a Yeti has 4 arms, I'm game, Yetis have 4 arms. If all the other Yetis have 2 arms, and all their ancestors have 2 arms, and we're told of at least one of these facts, now this needs addressing.*
> 
> Now, the rules of evolution properly applied millions of years backward is admittedly something you gotta let go of with any world not designed with the help of an evolutionary biologist or two. Instead, the go to rule is that creatures of the same species have forms little further apart than your typical pair of randomly selected humans.
> 
> Runeterra follows the latter rule, and the only hint that the former even exists is Gnar. Humans are humans, and every one of them that rises above the pack/becomes different gets explicit lore about him telling us why. Same with Yordles. Void creatures are explicitly different from each other because they don't originate in the same way normal life does outside of the void. We see one of plenty of species (Zyra, Nami, Soraka, Anivia, Bard, and Rengar to name a few) but have no reason the believe they are unique in the world. 
> 
> This, from a species perspective as we learn what we see, makes a couple problem children, but in fact the only examples I can find are yordles( either version of Willump is unique in our vision of the world. We have no comparison). Fizz has been brought up, and both tristana and lulu are lacking fur with purple skin. If it was just Lulu I'd say unstable transformation magic applied with questionable sanity, but tristana has no explanation here.
> 
> *It doesn't have to be addressed _well_. Radiation? Magic? Genetic manipulation? Sure, let's go.

Your ignoring fizz in the yordle example. (My bad, my brain skipped a line which I caught after I reread your  post) Andimerdinger, who literally has a brain on his head. (granted I believe there was lore explaining  that) actually as far as lore goes yordles look nearly nothing alike barring lulu and Tristana. And the rats. 
Fizz, blue fish looking creature. 
Teemo, furry rat
Lulu and Tristana both have puple skin, no fur 
Corkie, has a huge mustache. Otherwise we can't assume anything. Other then based on his lips and chin he is probably white with no hair. 
Heimer, very hairly similar to Teemo. 
Gnar, very hairly. However mega gnar looks nothing like any yordle so not sure how we explain that. 
Rumble, also very Harry and looks like a rat. Or a rodent of some sort. 
Based on Kennedy skins he is also furry. 
Poppy,also purple. 

So we have rumble, kennen, gnar, and Teemo who look like rodents. 

We have heimer and corkie who look more humanoid with rather intense facial hair

And Lulu poppy Tristana and fizz who are all hairless and different colors. 

Based on your reasoning this is all flawed. Based on a realistic approach it is. However in a land abundant in magic that the stories writers are constantly adding too it's far more likely that we just haven't been told yet. Obviously magic can have interesting results. 

Ffs ahri is a humanoid fox. Due to magic. And there was explicit interaction with magic in nunu's lore. So the correct assumption (assuming we should be doing those) would simply be to listen to the lore and assume that magic played a part. Not to go drawing all kinds of evolutionary parallels when we don't even know if evolution exists in the same way that it exists in the real world. Or if it exists at all. Like I said. Some cosmic entity could have created runeterra for little more then pleasure and without anyone knowing. Hell for all we know the aspects could have done it thousands of years ago as a combined powerful linked spell. 

But to assume evolution in the manor we understand it in the real world is akin to me simply deciding that the aspects joined hands 7.5 thousand years ago and created runeterra out of boredom and started demanding riot answer my questions based on that assumption. 

It makes no sense.

Again every story should have its own internal set of rules that govern it. Those can be as lose or specific as as one wants as long as it is consistent. However when there are clearly no rules in place it implies it is common knowledge and therefore should be based on reality unless otherwise specified.

> [{quoted}](name=Wayward Son,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=00020000000200000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-08-15T00:07:13.465+0000)
>
> Again every story should have its own internal set of rules that govern it. Those can be as lose or specific as as one wants as long as it is consistent. However when there are clearly no rules in place it implies it is common knowledge and therefore should be based on reality unless otherwise specified.

No. That's incorrect. No rules in place simply implies you haven't been told. Nothing about it implies its the same as reality.

> [{quoted}](name=Automated Riven,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=0002000000020000000000000000,timestamp=2018-08-15T00:01:09.566+0000)
>
> No. It's not safe to assume anything. That's rediculous. It's a world that you are allowed to see through slits in the wood. Your trying to rationalize everything. That's not how you can approach this. It's fair to ask questions. But your starting from the assumption that you understand the biology and chemistry of a world with magic. That's silly. 
> 
> Magic doesn't exist in this world. So based on that alone we should assume that the world is literally nothing like ours. There is literally no reason to assume that the laws which govern our world have any influence whatsoever on that world unless it's reflected in the stories. 
> 
> You first read the stories and try to figure out what you can and what is 'real' from them. And after that you can theory crafting and ask questions. You do not start from the assumption you understand everything and then wait for something to disprove you. It's an insult to the writer.

I agree with all of this! Plus let’s look at it this way, it’s a world forged by magic, has powerful magical runes...and there are creepy creachers that come from cracks that have very different anatomy from one another. {{champion:31}} {{champion:121}} {{champion:161}}

The void has its own internal logic and order to things that differ from the rest of the world. The primary one in this case is void creatures have exosceletons, which just like the real world counter parts exains the wide variety of body types.

> [{quoted}](name=Wayward Son,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=00020000,timestamp=2018-08-14T23:23:09.788+0000)
>
> But it is strange that yeti's evolved four arms, that would require major divergence from their last common ancestor. Not saying it's impossible but it is far more likely that there would be other species that evolved from a similar 6 limbed ancestor.

Lets not forget that is is a fantasy world...
The best fantasy worlds are still based off of the real one. With there own internal logic and history. Which is something Willump seemingly breaks.

.... How does Willump break this?   Just cuz there is no/very little prior existence of such creatures doesn’t invalidate them....   He’s a Yeti, a race of creatures we haven’t dealt with before.  Since they exist then they are validated.   Just because we don’t understand them doesn’t mean they just can’t exist.

Added to that, there seems to be an aspect of voluntary metamorphosis on the Yeti’s part, as it was revealed that the current model isn’t always what Willump looked like.  Creatures heavily impacted and shaped by magic often don’t follow the same baseline rules as our reality knows.  

If you want a rational explanation for it, that doesn’t involve “magic” u can think of it as a mutation that allowed for the formation of an extra pair of limbs, this mutation likely either helped or had no actual negative side effect so didn’t kill off the members of the species that had this “defect”. This defect either became a dominant trait innately, or in a bottleneck-founder effect way the population of multi-limbed yetis increased until they became the majority, thus the norm, eventually pushing out the single paired forms.




There’s still the fact however, that Yeti’s were originally magical (all of them apparently) but eventually many lost their affinity for magic.  Shaping and manipulating reality, so they could’ve originally  chosen to have the multiple pairs (as they might’ve served a purpose) and just never lost them.


On some level tho, Nunu’s imagination did help shape Willump into how we see him today (as said before, that wasn’t his original form).

We just don't know their evolutionary history. I imagine they're magical spirits of snow/ice analogous to drakalops, or maybe they have a vastaya-like evolutionary history that we're just unaware of. Either way, I'd say this is more us being uninformed than Riot being carelessly inconsistent.
Which is why I ask the question. It is something to elaborate on for better world building.
I don't think you'll find out. This is the type of question they don't answer.
Willump was created by Nunu. Their bio clearly shows how Willump came to look like that and it’s all because of Nunu’s imagination and his desire for a best friend named Willump. Just read their bio!
No the bio clearly states that there were Yetis before Nunu mmet Willump. As far as if the imagination power Willump gave nunu changed Willump or not is up in the air.

> [{quoted}](name=Wayward Son,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=00050000,timestamp=2018-08-15T00:02:18.736+0000)
>
> No the bio clearly states that there were Yetis before Nunu mmet Willump. As far as if the imagination power Willump gave nunu changed Willump or not is up in the air.

There were Yetis before him of course. But Yetis didn’t always look like that. Only Willump does. Read this. 
In that moment, the guardian knew the Freljord’s only hope lay in the power already within this child. The magic he’d been guarding was a tool; what truly mattered was the heart that would shape it. With a gesture, the magic passed from the gem into the boy, giving him the ability to make his imagination real. To repair his flute, freezing it in dreams that hardened into True Ice. 
To imagine a best friend named “Willump.”
Yes but that dose not imply one way or the other that Nunu imagined the extra arms, it could be taken either way. It does imply that the personality of Willump is Nunu's creation.

To support imgrabe's point, it is canon that, in part due to his extra arms, Willump is [the best hugger in Runeterra. This is indisputable fact.](https://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/en-us/2018/08/9-fun-facts-from-nunus-development/)  Even then, it's not hard to say that, in the Freljord's history, there might've been mammals that had six limbs.  Maybe six-finned fish evolved, and once they got to land the secondary fins were developed instead of opposable thumbs.  I can think of a few ways six limbs could've happened. But that's not the point.

I was going to go on, but I realized that everything I was going to say has probably been said already.  The rest is for you to agree or disagree with.  That's your choice.
In a world where this {{champion:105}} is from the same race as this {{champion:117}}... I think anything can be possible
Pretty sure Fizz is actually a form of Vastaya, not a Yordle. One that has the same general shape of a Yordle, sure, but still Vastaya.

> [{quoted}](name=DuskDaUmbreon,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=00030001,timestamp=2018-08-14T23:52:51.450+0000)
>
> Pretty sure Fizz is actually a form of Vastaya, not a Yordle. One that has the same general shape of a Yordle, sure, but still Vastaya.

fizz is a yordle

> [{quoted}](name=DuskDaUmbreon,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=00030001,timestamp=2018-08-14T23:52:51.450+0000)
>
> Pretty sure Fizz is actually a form of Vastaya, not a Yordle. One that has the same general shape of a Yordle, sure, but still Vastaya.

He is a yordle, it is stated literally in the first sentence of his bio.
Nope, Fizz is confirmed to be a Yordle. [It's stated in the 1st line of his lore on the universe site.](https://universe.leagueoflegends.com/en_US/champion/fizz/)

It’s pretty self explanatory if you read his lore. At least, I understand it.
{{sticker:sg-ezreal}}
Watchers are six-limbed too, iirc
Oh crap, that's a good point.
He was stated to change form depending on those who came to him, so I don't think it's that strange.
Old Willump isn’t canon, so why wouldn’t a fantasy creature have four arms?

If you read the bio it talks out Nunu approaching Willump and as he was getting closer Willumps appearance was changing to fit the child’s imagination. My guess is either yeti’s appearance are shapped by whoever is close to them imagination or The gem Willump was guarding had the ability to do so. I think the gem was a world rune and it infused itself with Nunu. That’s why the world around him is shaped by his imagination. But like the story says Willump is a yeti.
The only line that implies a change to physical appearance only mentions him being "furrier". It is possible that power changed Willump more than that, but that is only speculation.

> [{quoted}](name=Wayward Son,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=sm7pYAsE,comment-id=00070000,timestamp=2018-08-15T00:46:44.509+0000)
>
> The only line that implies a change to physical appearance only mentions him being "furrier". It is possible that power changed Willump more than that, but that is only speculation.

I still think because they are rebuilding stories that we don’t know all the properties of every magical element of Runeterra. Because of this we don’t need a detailed explanation of every aspect of the story. Good writers should allow the reader to use their imagination to form the world along with the actual words written. So hes a yeti.

He's a yeti. On a world called Runeterra, literally meaning "Magic Earth", which is EBGRUBGBGW full of magic.

Fucking wizards, man. How is this so goddamn impossible for people to understand?
